> Peter, how to represent the geometry of a rag doll in the substra=
te is
> an open question right now with a lot of possible answers.  The
> e=
asiest part of the answer is probably just that the inputs and
> outputs sh=
ould be in a configuration that is projected from the shape
> of the body, =
and both inputs and outputs should have correlated
geometry.
> 
> However, =
the little questions are the hard ones, like what to do when
> there are mu=
ltiple degrees of freedom at the same location (such as a
> hip).  It seems=
 erroneous to simply squeeze such different directions
> arbitrarily into t=
he same area. Perhaps more useful would be to have
> multiple input and out=
put layers, each with a map of the joints of the
> body that rotate along a=
 certain axis.
> 
> The multiple layers could be joined together on a 3rd d=
imension, or
> effectively completely separated by making them separate inp=
uts or
> outputs (i.e. by having multiple sets of inputs or outputs).  
> 
=
> To simplify the problem, you might start out for practice with a robot
> =
that only has a single degree of freedom at each joint.  That way, you
> co=
uld just have a single input map and a single output map without any
> diff=
icult conceptual issues.  If it works out well, you could expand
> from the=
re to more complex representations.
> 
> Like I said, this research area is=
 an experiment in progress, but I do
> believe we will eventually have some=
 standard practices for how to
> project a body onto a substrate.  I'd be i=
nterested in hearing
> anything you find out.
> 
> ken
